awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Concurrent Design of Quasi-Random Nanostructured Material Systems (NMS) and Nanofabrication Processes using Spectral Density Function
awd_abstract_narration:
This award supports an interdisciplinary research to create a novel concurrent design framework that unifies the design of functional quasi-random nano/microstructures and the design of nanofabrication processes to accelerate the development of robust nanostructured material systems with superior performance.  Quasi-random nanostructures are playing an increasingly important role in developing advanced material systems with various functionalities.  These structures comprise no periodic repetition of identical unit-cells but a seemingly random material distribution with underlying spatial correlation.  Compared to periodic designs that usually require expensive and time intensive fabrications, quasi-random nanostructures can be synthesized by low-cost and scalable manufacturing processes.  However, due to the lack of appropriate computational design paradigms, there is often a mismatch between microstructure designs and feasible nanofabrication techniques.  Although the testbed is focused on organic photovoltaic cells, this research will establish the applicability of the approach for a wide range of microstructural systems where the properties/performance of interest mainly depends on the spatial correlations instead of local geometries of microstructures. The broad range of potential industrial and military applications includes bio-medical devices, ultra-strong materials, consumer electronics, photonics, and telecommunications using nano-scale structures/devices.  The research also offers unique collaborative experiences for researchers across the fields of design, nanomanufacturing, materials, and mechanics.  Research will be integrated with education through cross-university teaching and assessment, and co-located and co-advised student training.

The concurrent design approach creates a shift from existing deterministic computational materials engineering to non-deterministic microstructure design that is compatible with the intrinsic stochasticity of bottom-up nanomanufacturing processes. The key novelty is to use the physics-aware Spectral Density Function, a non-deterministic microstructure representation, as the link between the processing-structure and the structure-performance mappings in the design of engineered material systems. The approach facilitates rapid exploration of feasible and compatible processing and structure solutions, with a significantly reduced design dimensionality.  An atomic resolution high-performance computational exploration will be achieved using coarse grained molecular dynamics to understand the fundamental transport mechanisms based on the materials processing dependent evolution of the structural morphologies.  The bottom-up fabrication processes and multiscale imaging techniques created will offer a platform for validation of the approach, calibration and validation of computational findings, and deep scientific discovery. Finally, in addition to the intrinsic robustness of quasi-random nanostructures, the approach offers robust nanostructured material systems designs considering not only the variations in processing conditions but also the uncertainty of the computer model itself.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
This interdisciplinary collaborative research project addresses the challenges in designing complex microstructural material systems to simultaneously achieve performance optimality and nanofabrication feasibility.  The broad research objective is to create a novel concurrent design framework that unifies the design of quasi-random nano/microstructures and the design of scalable nanomanufacturing processes to accelerate the development of high-performance, cost effective, and robust nanostructured material systems (NMS). 

 

Our objective has been achieved through research developments under four interrelated modules: (1) XSTM/S and Spectral Density Function (SDF) based Microstructure Characterization & Reconstruction; (2) Coarse-Grained Molecular Dynamics (CGMD) based Processing Structure Modeling; (3) Structure Performance Modeling and Bottom-up Fabrication; and (4) Concurrent Design and Validation. Through the synergy of experts in computational materials design, materials characterization and nanofabrication, and mechanics, a concurrent design strategy rooted in ?microstructure mediated design? has been developed using SDF as the stochastic representation of microstructures. The hybrid computational-experimental approach integrates diverse data from molecular computations, microstructure characterization, and device performance validation. The design of the bulkheterojunction (BHJ) structure in the organic photovoltaic cells (OPVC) has been used as a testbed to illustrate and validate the proposed methodology.

 

The developed systematic design approach creates a shift from existing deterministic computational materials engineering to non-deterministic microstructure design that is compatible with the intrinsic stochasticity of bottom-up nanomanufacturing processes. The key novelty of this work is the use of the physics-aware SDF, a stochastic microstructure representation, as the link between the processing-structure and the structure-performance mappings in the design of engineered material systems. Beyond the existing approaches, SDFs can model complex morphologies with arbitrary microstructure geometries and the key parameters in SDF have direct associations with functional performance and the materials formation processes in nanofabrication. Therefore, the approach facilitates rapid exploration of feasible and compatible processing and structure solutions, with a significantly reduced design dimensionality. The use of CGMD simulations to understand the processing dependent evolution of structural morphologies makes significant strides in developing a robust predictive methodology to establish the processing-structure-performance relationships. The bottom-up fabrication processes and multiscale imaging techniques created for OPVC offer a platform for validation of the SDF approach, calibration and validation of computational findings, and deep scientific discovery. Finally, in addition to the intrinsic robustness of quasi-random nanostructures, our approach offers robust NMS designs considering not only the variations in processing conditions but also the uncertainty of the computer model itself. 

 

For practical impact, OPVC has its own niche in the future renewable energy road map. This is mainly because OPVC has a combination of advantages in flexibility, low cost, and environmental friendly. Recent development in OPVC pushed the power conversion efficiency (PCE) up to 13% (with bulkheterojunction) and to 15 % (with tandem structure) which showed a promising future of the OPVC. This project results in an optimized PCE with bulkheterojunction OPVC, which is highly valuable for technology transfer toward commercial applications. 

 

Although the testbed is focused on OPVC devices, the proposed research establishes the applicability of the SDF approach for a wide range of microstructure systems where the properties/performance of interest mainly depends on the spatial correlations instead of local geometries of microstructures. The broad range of potential industrial and military applications includes bio-medical devices, ultra-strong materials, consumer electronics, photonics, material science and telecommunications using nano-scale structures/devices.  The use of machine learning approaches integrated with computational materials models is offering new channels for data-science to impact research in organic chemistry and physics. 

 

The project has offered unique collaborative experiences for researchers across the fields of design, nano-manufacturing, materials, and mechanics. Research has been integrated with education through cross-university teaching and assessment, co-located and co-advised student training, exchange visits, innovation and leadership experiences, and participation of undergraduate researchers. Based on the research results, teaching materials have been developed for interdisciplinary learning in the Mechanical Engineering courses at Lehigh University, as well as for the hands-on training through Global Social Impact projects. Datasets collected from both simulations and experiments are made available through publications.  Finally, outreach activities at three collaborative institutions have been utilized to promote scientific socialization of a wide gamut of audience to ensure awareness and encouragement for STEM education.


Last Modified: 11/13/2022
Modified by: Ganesh Balasubramanian

    Adaptive batch sampling for OPVC optimization

    ACS Appl. Polym. Mater. 2020, 2, 335−341
    Copyrighted
    Ganesh Balasubramanian
    Elongated nano domain with electric field application
